commits.commit_title:
Fix addresses being represented as uintptr_t

As of commit f3c8d248a198 ("Make Addr a u64") all addresses were
supposed to be represented as 64 bit integers. However, that changed did
not adjust the C API bindings. Usually that would have been picked up
transparently in the C header, except that cbindgen required us to
explicitly specify the address type, leading to a mismatch. Fix it up.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

capi: Rename blaze_result to blaze_syms

Rename the blaze_result type to blaze_syms, which more aptly reflects
the intention and will help with future API extensions. Furthermore
rename blaze_result_free() to blaze_syms_free() to preserve consistency.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

capi: Use our "Input" terminology in C API

There is a divergence between the terminology we use for the Input enum
in Rust code and the suffixes we added to the symbolization functions in
the C API.
This change unifies the two to minimize the potential for confusion.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

Introduce Input enum for symbolization APIs

With upcoming changes we are going to rework what amount of work is
performed as part of normalization (#321). As a result of this rework,
normalization will produce file offsets as opposed to (normalized)
addresses.
In order to keep supporting end-to-end symbolization workflow where the
output of normalization is fed to the symbolization APIs, this change
introduces the Input enum. This enum can be used to convey to the
symbolization APIs what kind of input is being provided. Not all sources
support all input types and a runtime error will be reported if an
unsupported input combination is used. This enum effectively formalizes
(via the type system) part of what previously was implicit knowledge:
that different symbolization sources require different inputs.
Specifically, process symbolization will work with what we refer to as
absolute addresses while ELF/Gsym will work with virtual offsets.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

Rename blazesym_result -> blaze_result

Rename blazesym_result to blaze_result. Ultimately we want to rename it
to something more meaningful or get rid of it altogether, but as a first
step just fix up the prefix to unblock the alpha release.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

Rename blazesym_ssc_ stuff

Rename blazesym_ssc_ stuff to blaze_symbolize_src_* to improve
readability and for the sake of consistency with existing inspect APIs.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

Split blaze_symbolize C API into various variants

Split the blaze_symbolize C API function into blaze_symbolize_{process,
kernel, elf, gsym} variants. This allows us to eliminate a bunch of
union usage, which is really not very convenient for users (or
implementors, for that matter).

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

capi: Rename blaze_result to blaze_syms

Rename the blaze_result type to blaze_syms, which more aptly reflects
the intention and will help with future API extensions. Furthermore
rename blaze_result_free() to blaze_syms_free() to preserve consistency.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

There is a divergence between the terminology we use for the Input enum

This change unifies the two to minimize the potential for confusion.

Signed-off-by: Daniel M眉ller <deso@posteo.net>

With upcoming changes we are going to rework what amount of work is
